body.head: STATEMENT OF MISS MARY MILES MINTER. G.H BOONE OFFICIAL REPORTER IN THE DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE, February 7, 1922, at five o'clock P.M.
body.ab: PRESENT: Mr. W.C. Doran, Deputy District Attorney, Miss Mary Miles Minter, John G. Mott, attorney for Miss Minter, and G. H. Boone, shorthand reporter. ---o--- STATEMENT OF MISS MARY MILES MINTER Questions by Mr. Doran:

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Did he declare his love for you, whi1e rid1ng around in the machine?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: No, he did not.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Not until you reached the studio did he do tha that?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: Not until after we had been there a long time at the studio.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Was it before or after he told you about this instance in connection with Taylor --

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: It was afterwards. I don't know yet whether he really meant it; maybe he was as sincere as he could be, and he can be very sincere, I am sure. I am sure he can.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: This was the second time that he had declared love for you. On one occasion he proposed to you?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: Yes.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: He asked you to marry him?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: Yes, and then he would dart away again. I mean he would call me up -- He can't call me up, because I have no telephone; he would send me flowers, too, and suddenly I would not hear from him for two or three weeks. As I said to him in the car, not particularly about that but about other things, about dinner engagements, about & appointments, I said, "You know, Marshall, I never know when l am going to see you and when I am not going to see you, and just what you are going to do, and I am in no mood to go on like that at all; I don't care much about it."

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: When did you tell him that?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: I told him that when we were driving the car.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: How old a man is Marshall Neilan?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: Just thirty.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Has he ever been married?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: Yes, he has been married once for a few days. He remained married to his wife for a long time, for seven years, I think, but he was actually only married a few days. I think he married when he was twenty or nineteen.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Have you seen him since this Friday night?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: No, I have not.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Have you talked with him over the telephone?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: It was really Saturday morning.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Has he called you up on the telephone?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: No; he may have called me at the New Hampshire house and I wouldn't know.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: You haven't talked with him over the telephone?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: I haven't seen him or talked to him or come in touch with him in any way

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: You haven't received any letters from him?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: No.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: Did you part friendly or unfriendly?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: We did part more or less friendly, as I always did with Marshall, no matter how angry I would become with him, somehow you can't bear malice against that boy.

sp.speaker: DORAN:
sp.ab: You have become angry with him on other occasions?

sp.speaker: MINTER:
sp.ab: Yes. This night for the time being, I was furious [missing page] [...] Mr Neilan -- Taylor's, and at the time of Mr Taylor's death, Harry was the assistant director in Mr Taylor's companies there, and he had said Harry had been in the room looking over the effects -- Just a minute. I wonder if Charles Maigne told me this. I think Mr Neilan told me this, too, that Harry bad gotten the letters and taken them to Jim Vantrees, the camera man, whereupon I remarked, "I will bet Mrs Ivers had them," and I think he said, "Jim gave them to Mr Eyton," and that Mr Eyton turned some of them over to the Examiner. I am so afraid l am telling things that are not so here, Mr Doran; I don't mean to, but I couldn't get all of it. That is as clear as I can make it. Anyway, I do remember this part, he said he heard about them, and I don't know how he heard about them, and that he went down, I believe, to the Examiner, to get ahold of them and he had something to do with Pasadena, a man, he did tell me the man's name. I don't remember his name, but I believe it beÂ­gan with "S", and this man, Marshall said he was the big man over the entire Examiner force, told him to go down and take the letters. He said, "Of course, if you breathe this it wi11 just about throw me in jail for the rest of my life," but I don't believe it will. Then he said, "Didn't you get them today?" I said, "I did not." As well as I remember, Marshall said, "I then sent them to the Realart Studio and they ought to be in Charley's hands now or Mr Garbut." This whole Friday night is most hasy in my recollection.
